api.title: üåê API Simulation
api.subtitle: Practice API testing with different HTTP status codes
api.description: Simulate different API responses by clicking the buttons below. Check the status code and response message.
api.booksDescription: Full CRUD operations for managing a digital library.

postmanSteps.step5: 5. Go to Body > raw > JSON and paste the request body (if needed)

getBooks.description: Retrieves a list of all available books in the library.

getBookById.description: Retrieves a specific book using its unique ID.

createBook.description: Adds a new book to the library.

updateBook.description: Updates an existing book's information by ID.

deleteBook.description: Removes a book from the library permanently.

comparison.title: üîç Cypress, Selenium, and Playwright Command Comparison
comparison.conclusionText: Each tool has its own strengths:
comparison.seleniumStrength: Mature, flexible, wide language and browser support
comparison.playwrightStrength: Modern, fast, powerful API and network control
comparison.finalAdvice: Choose the most suitable tool according to your project requirements, team skills, and test scope.

locator.title: üéØ Selenium vs Playwright Locator Guide
locator.subtitle: Migration from Java Selenium to TypeScript Playwright

headers.playwrightOnlyFeatures: üé≠ The following features are only available in Playwright!

tips.comp1: CSS selectors are default in Playwright. Use # for ID.
tips.comp3: Use square brackets for Attribute selectors.
tips.comp4: Role-based selectors in Playwright are more accessible and reliable.
tips.comp5: Using getByRole is faster and more readable than XPath.
tips.comp6: CSS selectors work the same way in both frameworks.
tips.comp7: Playwright's getByPlaceholder method is much more practical.
tips.comp8: getByLabel is much cleaner than complex XPaths.
tips.comp9: Using role-based selectors for headings is best practice.
tips.comp10: Test IDs are the most reliable selectors in test environments.
tips.comp11: In Playwright, locator captures multiple elements automatically.
tips.comp12: You can do partial text search with getByText.
tips.comp13: getByAltText is the best option for images.
tips.comp14: Chained selectors are cleaner in Playwright.
tips.comp15: Using role for checkboxes is a more semantic approach.
tips.comp16: You can use selectOption() method for dropdowns.
tips.comp17: getByRole('cell') can also be used for tables.
tips.comp18: getByTitle is very practical for title attributes.
tips.comp19: Locator chaining is more readable in Playwright.
tips.comp20: Combining with dot is the same for multiple classes.
tips.pw1: You can select the first of multiple elements with first().
tips.pw2: last() selects the last element in the list.
tips.pw3: You can select the element at a specific index with nth(index). Index starts from 0.
tips.pw4: You can filter elements by text or other criteria with filter().
tips.pw5: You can find a parent containing a specific element with has.
tips.pw6: You can check element state with Playwright assertion methods.
tips.pw7: You can easily check element states (enabled/disabled).
tips.pw8: Special methods are available for checkbox operations.
tips.pw9: toHaveText checks exact match, toContainText checks partial match.
tips.pw10: Checking or getting input values is very easy.
tips.pw11: You can check class existence with string or regex.
tips.pw12: You can check any HTML attribute or get its value.
tips.pw13: You can check or get the count of found elements.
tips.pw14: You can easily check link href and page URL.
tips.pw15: Playwright automatically waits for elements to be ready!
tips.pw16: You can make more specific selections by chaining locators.
tips.pw17: You can select from dropdown in 3 different ways.
tips.pw18: You can easily access elements inside iframe with frameLocator.
tips.pw19: You can get all elements as array with all() and loop through them.
tips.pw20: You can upload files even to hidden file inputs.
